ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned a lot not only about colonial and postcolonial theory but also about Russian imperial history.
A better grasp of the most foundational texts for understanding postcolonial studies, as applied to the Russian context
Close reading, discussion skills, general understanding of post-colonial discourse.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Strengths: effective combination of theoretical and literary material, engaging discussions, interesting and helpful writing assignments Weakness: some weeks, the reading list was a bit too long such that we were rushing through material
Slightly too much reading each week, especially for primary sources

The course was helpful in that it tackled important texts in both 19th-century Russian literary canon and Orientalist/post-colonial discourse. However, the amount of reading was sometimes overwhelming.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! Professor Bojanowska is a committed and excellent instructor and the material is interesting and opens up so many avenues for new research in Russian literature and history.

I would strongly recommend this course to anyone who is interested in the topic because you will get to read all the core texts of the discipline and meet a group of people who are also interested in the same discipline and share ideas and feedbacks.
